title: #60: What PM candidates get wrong about behavioral interviews | Robert Hamilton (PM interview coach)

rawLines.text: because it can feel like almost as a
candidate you're thinking am I not
allowed to be good at my job can we not
talk about a time when I crushed it
because I have crushed it and the fact
that you're in the room in that in that
loop at any of the big companies means
you have got a successful career as a PM
so it feels a little uncomfortable that
someone's jab the times you didn't make
it work and you think but look at those
three launches that I did or look at
that amazing idea that I had and the
person's like actually could we tell me
about another struggle or another
failure so there's a lot of psychology
in there and we'll talk maybe more about
why companies use these questions and
what they're looking for. It' be good to
get into that. But that's my origin
story, if I can use that phrase. And it
goes way back to to not liking it and
then learning to love
[Music]
it. Hey everyone and welcome to another
episode of Supra Insider. This is a
conversation I've been really excited to
have because the number one thing people
ask me about after taking my product
sense and analytical thinking course is
do you have any resources for leadership
and drive interviews at a lot of other
companies are these are called
behavioral interviews and I have been
trying to find more and more good
resources for those to link people to
and Robert Hamilton who's our guest
today is one of those resources. Robert
is an executive coach for PMs and
product leaders. He spent years at Meta,
working on Oculus, Facebook, and he's
also spent almost eight years at Google
in product management. Robert's also
worked in startups and just gets a ton
of satisfaction and meaning out of
coaching people on storytelling and
structuring behavioral interview
responses. He also does product sense
and analytical thinking coaching that I
do, but he loves to go deep on some of
the stuff that I don't cover. So, in
this conversation, we went really deep
on what makes behavioral interviews so
powerful and tricky for both candidates
and interviewers. We covered some
practical tips for how to structure
compelling stories using Robert's
modified STAR framework. So, he adds a
couple more letters to it, which we'll
cover. and what kind of pitfalls
candidates fall into when walking
through their stories in these kind of
structured interviews and why it's so
critical to be authentic and bring
vulnerability into storytelling. Whether
you're preparing for interviews for a
leadership role, a product management,
or any other function really, and you
want to tell your story better, I think
this conversation is going to be
extremely helpful. Without further ado,
let's dive into this conversation with
Robert Hamilton. Thanks.
If you enjoy this conversation, don't
forget to subscribe to the podcast on
your favorite podcasting app. Follow us
on Substack. Give us a rating. It'll
help us a ton and help future people
discover us while also making sure you
never miss an episode. Thank you. All
right, we're live. Robert, thank you so
much for joining us. Thank you both.
Great to see you today. Good to see you,
Robert. Good to see you, Ben. Yeah, this
is going to be a fun one. Or at least
one I've been really looking forward to.
Some context for what got me excited
about this conversation is that I teach
a course that's focused on product sense
and analytical thinking interviews and
those are I think people consider them
like case style interviews that are
happening at places like Meta and a lot
of other companies and when I talk to my
students and the folks that I work with
on basically what else could I do to be
helpful to you or what are the biggest
gaps in kind of like my syllabus or my
curriculum that could be helpful
behavioral interviews and specifically
at companies like meta leadership and
drive interviews are the number one
thing that I'm hearing from my students
that they want more materials about. And
when I double click into it, I realize
there's a like a big gap in the market
for good content that people that really
resonates for people. So, there's a
craving for more of it. In this
conversation, I think we have an
opportunity to go deep on on behavioral
interviews and to create something
that's going to be extremely helpful for
the people that I've been talking to and
a lot of other people in the market. So,
great way to really excited about that.
Yeah. No, not to not to hype you up, but
you do stand out to me as one of the
limited number of coaches that I've
worked with so far, at least who I've
partnered with who have a very
compelling way of explaining a lot of
behavioral interviewing that resonates
for me and I've talked to some people
that don't. Like there's uh so anyways,
I'm really excited to have you here and
I think my first question for you just
to get things rolling is what gets you
excited about behavioral interviews and
why are you spending a lot of time
there? I know you do other things too,
not just behavioral interviews, but what
gets you excited about those in
particular? Yeah, the thing about
behavioral interviews and I'm over
feeling uncomfortable about being
interested in them. So, initially it was
like really you're into that. And it's
like, well, actually, yes, I am. And I'm
prepared to talk about it. So, it's kind
of why I'm here, I guess. When I was at
Meta, when I joined Meta, I had a
realization about behavioral interviews.
So, as you said, Ben, the Meta
behavioral interview is leadership and
drive. And when I did the training for
that, it felt quite uncomfortable
because a lot of the leadership and
drive questions are pushing people about
times they struggle, times when they
couldn't make things work, really
challenging situations. And it really
feels almost like you're picking on the
person in the interview. And I wasn't
really comfortable. The first few L & D
interviews I did. And obviously I'd
passed an L & D loop because I I had to
do one to get hired at Meta. But the
first few I was really uncomfortable.
But then actually I got to enjoy it more
than the case interviews, the domain
interviews as we sometimes call them
that you were talking about because
every behavioral interview is so
different as an interviewer. You have to
really listen intently because being
honest and I don't think this is a big
secret. If I ask somebody how they
improve Google Maps, I can sit on 20%
brain power and listen and know whether
their answer is any good because I've
heard dozens possibly hundreds of
answers to that question and I'll be
able to tell. But when somebody's
telling me their story about a time when
they struggled to convince leadership of
an idea or they couldn't create a
successful partnership with a key
colleague, anything like that, I really
have to listen intently because it's
their story. It's unique to them. And
then so that's one part of it is that as
an interviewer, you have to be more
engaged. And then the second reason why
as an interviewer, the interviews are
interesting and why I've got into
coaching them is
because again, when I do a case
interview, I pretty much know the
questions I'm going to ask. In fact, I
knew last week what I was going to do,
what I was going to do and how I was
going to construct the interview. But
with a behavioral interview, bit like
this conversation, we go where it leads.
And so if I get certain signals from
someone's initial answers and I think,
well, I'm getting a lot of empathy. They
seem like a servant leader, but I'm not
getting a lot of a sense of ownership,
then I have to change my tack and start
asking questions which lead to
ownership. And of course, I'm not going
to ask something like, "How do you
demonstrate taking ownership?" That's
just like an open goal. It's too easy.
But I do have to I think of it almost
sometimes as picking a lock. I've got to
pick the next tool to get me past the
next lever because by the end of the
interview it's my job to really have a
deep understanding of that person which
is not that easy in 354 minutes but it
really is the most challenging interview
and going from someone who was
uncomfortable about them initially was
like I really don't want to do an L & D
I actually vastly preferred them in the
end and they are not that pleasant even
as a candidate or as an interviewer
because you are digging into tough
things and I was working with a client
last week who was preparing for a meta L
& D and they said I'm glad you told me
it was going to be 35 minutes talking
about times when I failed or struggled
because it can feel like almost as a
candidate you're thinking am I not
allowed to be good at my job can we not
talk about a time when I crushed it
because I have crushed it and the fact
that you're in the room in that in that
loop at any of the big companies means
you have got a successful career as a PM
so it feels a little uncomfortable that
someone's jab at the times you didn't
make it work and you think but look at
those three launches that I did or look
at that amazing idea that I had and the
person's like, "Actually, could we tell
me about another struggle or another
failure?" So, there's a lot of
psychology in there and we'll talk maybe
more about why companies use these
questions and what they're looking for.
It' be good to get into that, but that's
my origin story. If I can use that
phrase and it goes way back to to not
liking it and then learning to love it.
curious maybe to like some grounding to
have you seen most companies in for
product leadership roles do behavioral
interviews and do they call them
behavioral interviews or because you
know I noticed like for example like
Meta called them leadership and drive I
guess what I'm trying to get at is like
how do you know if you're about to get
into a behavioral interview and then
also like how do you get signal before
you do that interview of what are the
attributes or the value that those
companies look for because it sounds
like meta for example they were looking
for maybe like growth growth mindset and
ownership and leadership. I think those
attributes are mostly the same. They
might be a little bit different in some
organizations, but I think they're
mostly the same for PMs. And Meta, one
of the good things about Meta's
interview process is it is very honest
and rigorous. So, you are not going to
get a behavioral question during your
product sense interviews and you're not
going to get an analytical question in
your behavioral interview. So, they're
very disciplined about what questions
come where. But other companies may just
go behavioral on you at any point. So I
think it's a great question, Mark, to to
say, how do I know? And maybe we can
talk about some of the pitfalls of
behavioral questions. And we're kind of
diving straight into the detail, but I
guess it goes where it goes. Like I
said, here's an example of when people
don't spot that it's a behavioral
question. So if you get asked, tell me
about a time when you rallied people
around an idea. That is not a question
about an idea. The question, tell me
about an idea you rallied people
around, is about an idea. Now, lots of
people might say, "Oh, you're splitting
hairs." Yeah, I'm a product manager.
That's my job is to spot small
differences and spot trade-offs, right?
So, I'm a former product manager. I'm
clean now. I'm out. But the um the wait
and actually can I ask a quick follow up
there? Yeah, of course. Yeah. If because
the distinction that you made is very
subtle, right? And I think let's say I'm
a little bit nervous in the interview
and I miss that subtlety. But you have
an inkling of hey there might be two
things as here. Is it fair to ask the
question back to the interviewer? Hey
are you more interested in the idea or
are you more interested in like how I
got the team excited about the idea?
Exactly. how you show up, how you got
the team excited and and you saw that
and it is subtle and I use that
deliberately because it is very subtle
and people are like they're the same
thing and they're not because
mostly the interviewer if they say tell
me about a complex technical project you
worked on that's probably a technical
question. they're interested in the
project and the problem that you solved.
But when it mentions people, when it
mentions persuasion, when it mentions
those softer aspects of things, again,
if someone said, "Tell me about the
biggest growth product you worked on or
growth project you worked on," they
probably do want to hear about your
growth tactics. But you can ask, and you
should always ask, and I think
particularly for senior candidates,
feeling comfortable saying, "I can tell
you the nuts and bolts of what we did.
Would you also like me to talk about my
contribution?" And that's where again if
you only talk about the project I
sometimes call this handover mode where
I learn so much about the project or the
problem that the team was solving that I
feel I could go and run the standup for
the team tomorrow and I'm like no I
don't want to know about your project I
want to know about you and so this is a
great question mark you do need to ask
and again try and balance that and one
thing that I recommend folks do in all
interviews is Whenever you think you've
finished a little section and we'll talk
about star and some other stuff in I'm
sure at some point this today when you
think you've introduced the project say
would you like more detail on the
project background before I go on to
talk about what I did and that gives the
interviewer the opportunity if they do
want more project detail to say yeah how
many people were on the team how long
did the project take who were the
stakeholders you had to get by for
that's a sign that they want more what
what you worked on rather than how you
worked on it And I always recommend that
because when an interviewer usually goes
and looks at their notes, sometimes a
day later, sometimes a couple of days
later, if they look at their notes and
think, "Oh, they didn't give me much
project detail," then it's too late. The
call ended two days ago. They're going
to write up their notes for the hiring
committee or whatever their process is,
and you've lost your chance. Whereas, if
you say, "I can give you more technical
detail if you'd like. Otherwise, I'm
going to talk about my contribution."
That way, you are taking out insurance,
as I call it. It's like an insurance
policy with the interviewer to because
time management is your job in all
interviews. You have to make sure you're
getting to the end. But you also want to
make sure that you are giving the
interviewer what they want. So there are
many ways to phrase that. You can you
can say I can get into this in more
detail. Would you like to hear more
about is there part of this I can
explain in more depth? There's you can
practice that over and over. And it's
just a great way of saying I feel like
I'm done. If you don't agree, I can keep
going because we want PMs who
demonstrate a mastery of the detail with
an ability to cover the ground. And
those two things are intention, right?
We have to feel like you could talk in
absolute very specific intimate details
of the problem or the project. But we
also want the discipline that in a few
minutes time you'd have got to the end
of your answer. And those two things are
intention for most people. Most people
will either be too brief or too long.
And that's why you got to practice. The
same I would say the same applies to the
product sense and analytical thinking,
right? It's like we want people who can
pace themselves well to cover all the
ground in those structured case style
interviews and check in with you to make
sure you're getting the signal you need
before they keep going. And it sounds
like you you're generally coaching
something similar for like the
leadership and drive interviews.
Absolutely. I think say in product sense
we used to say at Google when you're
interviewing for product designers was
you want that to get the feeling that
this person could talk about this
problem all day that they have so much
intellectual curiosity and passion even
if it's something they've never worked
on probably it is something they never
worked on that oh wow this is
interesting I could talk about it all
day however I'm going to be disciplined
and deliver an answer in 20 minutes and
that to me sums up the tension in both
it's more more true in product sense
than analytical But but it's definitely
true Ben and I think I think as you
coach it for those disciplines it's
equally valid coming back to leadership
and drive. So if I tell people usually a
45minut product sense interview is going
to cover one product or one question and
then analytical thinking you're going to
probably cover one product with a
trade-off question about that same
product at the end. When an interviewer
at a company like Meta is approaching a
leadership and drive interview in your
experience, how many questions will
typically come up in a call it like a 45
minute slot? I would say probably five
or six. So, you know, you're looking at
and one of the things in leadership and
drive the follow-up questions are the
real questions.
So once I've asked that when did you
struggle to build a partnership and you
tell me a little bit then where I go and
say what was the hardest part about that
for you or what do you think the other
person felt about that situation the
follow-up questions is where I get the
real signal because I probably know that
the candidate has at least thought about
the first part and then I get my chance
to push them around a little bit not to
trap them or trick them but just to see
have you just rehearsed a good answer or
do you Have you actually got a
perspective on this? So that's why the
questions go probably if we do the maths
that suggests they're just over 5
minutes long, maybe five and a half,
maybe 6 minutes because there's the
initial kind of opening rally. And then
there's the follow-up questions. And of
course, they're not equally balanced. So
you might end up on one that contains a
lot of detail, but usually it's it's of
that order. I would say four, five, or
six. four would seem I would be very
impressed by an L & D interviewer who
could get the full pallet of behaviors
from four questions. There's a challenge
thrown out there part partly because it
totally depends on how the candidate
reacts because if there were four magic
questions we would know them and we
would use them, right? So like you know
that that would that would be known. So
as I say I I would go back to it. It
needs a few questions. I'm curious. So
it sounds like it's obviously important
to have that initial story well
prepared, right? So you're able to cover
all the grounds and really share the
behaviors that question once they get
signal on, but I'm curious what can you
do as a candidate to like really also
make sure there's depth on that
follow-up question, right? What are some
things you can do to prepare to make
sure that you're just you can anticipate
all the potential options or at least
like 80% of the options that might come
up as a follow-up? And this might be a
good chance to also hear your thoughts
on STAR because I know STAR might start
to fit into some of this. So feel free
to go where you want with that. So STAR
for those who haven't been tortured by
Amazon in an interview prep loop is a
situation, task, actions, and results.
And normally, and STAR is well
understood, so there's plenty of places
you can read about STAR. A couple of
quick comments on it. The S should be as
short as possible. And this is the piece
you're talking about Mark the kind of
the before bit the bit that that you
know and I know your question is about
what happens after star but I want to
talk quickly about star and then then
come to your question s is a situation
and again you're not handing over the
project to me you should give us as
little detail as you can in order for
the rest of the story to make sense and
I think we'll talk a bit more about
storytelling and storytelling tactics
perhaps because because I'd love to get
into that and hear your thoughts and I
have some questions for you as as well
today on thoughts on that and then T is
the task. Ideally, it's selfinitiated.
So, like based on the situation, I
realized I was going to have to go and
get extra resources, go and get help or
so, it's something that you derived.
That's much better than when it's
delegated to you. So, my boss asked me
to do this is a weaker T observed and so
I concluded that I should do this. So,
the best T's are selfinitiated. A is the
actions. A is what you did in order to
enact the T. So, how did I get extra
help? How did I get resources? And then
the R is the result. What happened as a
result of my efforts? So that's STAR in
a nutshell. I like to add two letters
which messes up the acronym but it helps
with the with being a stronger
candidate. So I had an L and a U and the
L is for learning. So I would usually
you can weave this in if you like and
some people's storytelling method. It
makes it easier for them to weave it in
than others. It doesn't have to come
neatly packaged at the end. But L is
what I learned through this process
because one of you mentioned growth
mindset and so on earlier like if it was
a difficult situation or even if it was
a big win for you and it wasn't so
difficult what did you learn and talking
about that and saying oh I realized that
if you're going to escalate escalating
early is probably a good thing don't
wait don't hope things are going to get
better that might be an example of the
learning now let's look at upgrade
upgrade is what you've changed about how
you work as a PM
because of that learning. So let's say
that I learned that escalating quickly
is a good thing. Now whenever I feel
like I might want to escalate, I ask
myself, is there any reason to wait? Is
there anything positive which might mean
I can wait before I escalate this
situation? And I always ask myself that.
So that's how I've upgraded my system
because of that learning about
escalating quickly. I have upgraded my
operating system. That's why I use the
word upgrade because we all learn things
all the time. and we don't apply them
systematically. And this is part of
having a growth mindset is looking for
ways to grow and then actually achieving
the growth. The growth doesn't come from
identifying the opportunity for growth.
Unfortunately, it's that's like buying
the gym membership, right? You still got
to turn up. So, the learning is the gym
membership. Going to the gym is the
upgrade. It's what am I doing
differently as a result of what I
learned? And that that piece is where
you get into the depth that is like how
you've changed what you do differently.
And sometimes there isn't something you
would do differently. If you think
something went well, it is okay to say
actually, you know what, I think that
was pretty good. I would do the same
again in the same situation. If you say
that every single time, it's not going
to go well. I had a candidate. I can say
they were a meta. It doesn't matter. I
spent 40 minutes trying to get them to
tell me about a situation that hadn't
gone well and every answer was I always
find a way or you know what I'll get it
done whatever or I'm actually really
good at this so I've never struggled
with it and the chances of them ever
seeing this are fairly low but a they're
not big on self-awareness so it's
unlikely they would recognize themselves
I know from having spent 40 minutes
trying to get them to admit to a a
problem or a mistake and they just
couldn't didn't see that that's what I
wanted. They were just desperate to
prove that I'm an amazing PM. I've never
made a mistake and unfortunately that's
just not plausible. But yeah, that
bringing in the learning and the upgrade
is the reflection and that's usually
where we're going with our follow-up
questions. Can I ask a quick question
there too? And so I think you bring a
good point about that candidate that
basically like it sounds like their
situation could be complicated, but it
sounds like that R was always like a big
win, right? And then there was maybe
Yeah. the results, sorry. And then the
learning was like, oh, I should just
keep doing the same and I'm the best, so
like I'm already like fully, you know,
actualized, aligned, so maybe I don't
have to change. But it sounds like that
might not be the way to go for these
interviews. There should be like a
balance of results are great, but maybe
results are big failures. Is that
accurate? Like having like a balance of
ours, of wins and losses. You don't have
to contrive losses, but you also don't
have to have a Hollywood ending for
everything.
Often a failure story is actually a
success story with the end cut off. So
if you don't quite get to the successful
part then it looks like a failure just
like oh you know which is kind of how
Hollywood works. So so you could you
could end the movie 5 minutes early
before everything's gone well. Again
don't look for failure but even in the
big Rs if you call them that the big
wins there should be some
self-reflection. I could have done this
earlier. I could have got that partner
involved in a different way and the
project would have gone better. Like it
it is unlikely given that in innovative
companies we're always solving new
problems of taking on things people
haven't done before. It's just unlikely
that you never put a foot wrong and that
you can't find a way to get better. And
so you know and you're always dealing
with different people and that I think
is in the nature of behavioral
interviews and it's something that this
didn't come up in interviewing at Google
but there was a phrase that we used to
use at Google computers are easy people
are hard and the reflection there is
that technical problems get solved if
the answer or if the problem can be
solved by writing code somebody will
write the code and the problem will go
away but the interesting problems the
ones that come up in behavioral
interviews are around people trust fear
anger uh when people start to talk about
these things, my team was nervous
because their previous project had been
shut down. So I realized I was going to
have to really boost their confidence to
give them the feeling that they could
succeed because last time round they'd
had a bit of a failure. There's so many
situations where people have
perspectives. Oh, Amanda and Caric
disagree over what architecture we
should use and it's harming. Sorry, I
was trying to say hurting and harming in
one word. um it is hurting the team
because we don't have a single vision at
the top. So this the fact that these two
people are disagreeing is holding the
team back. So again as a product manager
you've got to put your team's success as
your ultimate goal. So you don't have to
talk about successes and I wouldn't say
people should be looking for failure but
a lot of the questions will be directed
at struggles and in Meta's case there
are there are two closely aligned
reasons for that. We want to see how you
grow through difficult circumstances
because that is typically where most
growth occurs. We also want to
understand your attitude to risk because
if you are not operating outside your
comfort zone, you're probably not
pushing hard enough and you're probably
not going to be a great fit for meta.
You've got to be think I've never done
this before and I'm doing it anyway. Or
I don't know how to do this. I'm going
to try. And that's often where the
failure comes from. I'd never done it
before and my first swing was a terrible
miss and here's what I learned. And then
I took a few more swings and I'm still
not great at it, but I'm still in there.
I'm still batting. And that's why we ask
about the dark times. It's not because
we want to make you feel miserable for
40 minutes. That is not definitely not
the intent. It's that it's it's those
two things that often the best learnings
come from there and we want people who
grow from adversity rather than shrink
from it. And we also want people who
take on challenges rather than thinking
that looks a bit hard. I'll just stay
where I am. And again, I think once you
understand that and the web has
thousands of examples of how to do this,
of how to convince interviewers in in
the technical interviews and very few
good ones in on the behavioral side
because it's not so easy to relate to
somebody else's story about when they
couldn't establish trust with another
team. you look at it and think, "Yeah,
okay, but what about my story?" It
doesn't help you necessarily to watch
examples. I think um but that's why it's
great talking about it. And this is one
of the things that I think has made it
kind of it's one of the reasons I keep
kicking the can on trying to formalize
these kind of interviews into a course
or some kind of like framework is
because I do feel like there's so much
that is personal and there's so much
that is hard to generalize. How would
you design a parking solution for Google
Maps? Like you said, when we think about
and if we stay with meta for a second
because I know a lot of the people that
listen to this are probably thinking
about meta or at least if I send them to
this episode they will be. When we think
about the key dimensions that the
interviewer is looking to get signal on
in a leadership and drive interview. So
the first question was just a quick one
to make sure I'm following. In your
mind, is there generally a mapping
between those kind of five questions
that we talked about in the beginning,
the five highle questions, five or six
questions, and the evaluation dimension?
So like something like one question per
dimension is generally how you recommend
people have a story ready for each type
of question they might get asked. Yes.
Let's so at least one story for
ownership, servant leadership,
scrainess, being a convincing
communicator, all of those things. And
let's talk about the nature of stories.
I have a an analogy that I like to use
